abstract.p: Amy Virshup letter, commenting on Matthew Purdy's July 19 column, says toll collectors in New York do not have the friendly manner of toll collectors elsewhere in country

block.p: Re ''Inching Along in a Slow Lane to Frustration,'' by Matthew Purdy (Our Towns column, July 19):

Far be it for me to defend the manners of New York motorists, but area toll collectors might look within for some of their problems. Re ''Inching Along in a Slow Lane to Frustration,'' by Matthew Purdy (Our Towns column, July 19):

Far be it for me to defend the manners of New York motorists, but area toll collectors might look within for some of their problems. A few years ago, a friend and I drove across the United States, and all along the way we encountered friendly toll men and women who'd wish us a good day or welcome us to their state.

Then we hit the George Washington Bridge. The woman in the tollbooth had on her Walkman and sunglasses, the better to ignore us. As we stopped before her, she stared straight ahead, not deigning even to glance in our direction, and royally held out a white-gloved hand. My friend and I looked at each other and cried, ''We're home!''
